sub_topic: Finding the Fourier series of a function with a finite number of discontinuities
message_1: Find the Fourier series of the piecewise function $f(x)=\begin{cases} 0, & 0\le x < 2 \\ x-2, & 2\le x < 4 \\ 0, & 4\le x < 6\end{cases}$ with period $T=6$.
message_2:
To find the Fourier series of the given piecewise function with period $T=6$, we need to find the Fourier coefficients $a_0$, $a_n$, and $b_n$.

First, let's find the average value of the function, $a_0$:
$$a_0 = \frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} f(x) dx$$

Since the function is piecewise, we need to split the integral into three parts:
$$a_0 = \frac{1}{6} \left(\int_{0}^{2} 0 dx + \int_{2}^{4} (x-2) dx + \int_{4}^{6} 0 dx\right)$$

The first and third integrals are zero, so we only need to compute the second integral:
$$a_0 = \frac{1}{6} \int_{2}^{4} (x-2) dx = \frac{1}{6} \left[\frac{1}{2}x^2 - 2x\right]_{2}^{4} = \frac{1}{6}(4) = \frac{2}{3}$$

Now, let's find the coefficients $a_n$ and $b_n$:
$$a_n = \frac{2}{T} \int_{0}^{T} f(x) \cos\left(\frac{2\pi nx}{T}\right) dx$$
$$b_n = \frac{2}{T} \int_{0}^{T} f(x) \sin\left(\frac{2\pi nx}{T}\right) dx$$

Again, we need to split the integrals into three parts. Since the first and third parts of the function are zero, we only need to compute the second part:

$$a_n = \frac{2}{6} \int_{2}^{4} (x-2) \cos\left(\frac{2\pi nx}{6}\right) dx$$
$$b_n = \frac{2}{6} \int_{2}^{4} (x-2) \sin\left(\frac{2\pi nx}{6}\right) dx$$

Let's compute the integrals:

$$a_n = \frac{1}{3} \left[\frac{6}{2\pi n}\sin\left(\frac{2\pi nx}{6}\right) + \left(x-2\right)\cos\left(\frac{2\pi nx}{6}\right)\right]_{2}^{4}$$
$$a_n = \frac{1}{3} \left[\frac{6}{2\pi n}\left(\sin\left(\frac{4\pi n}{3}\right) - \sin\left(\frac{2\pi n}{3}\right)\right) + \left(2\cos\left(\frac{4\pi n}{3}\right) - 2\cos\left(\frac{2\pi n}{3}\right)\right)\right]$$

$$b_n = \frac{1}{3} \left[-\frac{6}{2\pi n}\cos\left(\frac{2\pi nx}{6}\right) + \left(x-2\right)\sin\left(\frac{2\pi nx}{6}\right)\right]_{2}^{4}$$
$$b_n = \frac{1}{3} \left[-\frac{6}{2\pi n}\left(\cos\left(\frac{4\pi n}{3}\right) - \cos\left(\frac{2\pi n}{3}\right)\right) + \left(2\sin\left(\frac{4\pi n}{3}\right) - 2\sin\left(\frac{2\pi n}{3}\right)\right)\right]$$

Now, we can write the Fourier series as:

$$f(x) \approx \frac{2}{3} + \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left[\frac{2}{\pi n}\left(\sin\left(\frac{4\pi n}{3}\right) - \sin\left(\frac{2\pi n}{3}\right)\right) + \left(2\cos\left(\frac{4\pi n}{3}\right) - 2\cos\left(\frac{2\pi n}{3}\right)\right)\right] \cos\left(\frac{2\pi nx}{6}\right) + \left[-\frac{2}{\pi n}\left(\cos\left(\frac{4\pi n}{3}\right) - \cos\left(\frac{2\pi n}{3}\right)\right) + \left(2\sin\left(\frac{4\pi n}{3}\right) - 2\sin\left(\frac{2\pi n}{3}\right)\right)\right] \sin\left(\frac{2\pi nx}{6}\right)$$
